user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_seek:
```c
int lfs_dir_seek(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, lfs_off_t off) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_seek(%p, %p, %"PRIu32")",
            (void*)lfs, (void*)dir, off);

    err = lfs_dir_seek_(lfs, dir, off);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_seek -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_seek:
static int lfs_dir_seek_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, lfs_off_t off) {
    // simply walk from head dir
    int err = lfs_dir_rewind_(lfs, dir);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // first two for ./..
    dir->pos = lfs_min(2, off);
    off -= dir->pos;

    // skip superblock entry
    dir->id = (off > 0 && lfs_pair_cmp(dir->head, lfs->root) == 0);

    while (off > 0) {
        if (dir->id == dir->m.count) {
            if (!dir->m.split) {
                return LFS_ERR_INVAL;
            }

            err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            dir->id = 0;
        }

        int diff = lfs_min(dir->m.count - dir->id, off);
        dir->id += diff;
        dir->pos += diff;
        off -= diff;
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static int lfs_dir_rewind_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    // reload the head dir
    int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->head);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    dir->id = 0;
    dir->pos = 0;
    return 0;
}
...
static inline int lfs_pair_cmp(
        const lfs_block_t paira[2],
        const lfs_block_t pairb[2]) {
    return !(paira[0] == pairb[0] || paira[1] == pairb[1] ||
             paira[0] == pairb[1] || paira[1] == pairb[0]);
}
...
static int lfs_dir_fetch(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_mdir_t *dir, const lfs_block_t pair[2]) {
    // note, mask=-1, tag=-1 can never match a tag since this
    // pattern has the invalid bit set
    return (int)lfs_dir_fetchmatch(lfs, dir, pair,
            (lfs_tag_t)-1, (lfs_tag_t)-1, NULL, NULL, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_dir {
    struct lfs_dir *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t head[2];
} lfs_dir_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No usages of the C library function memcmp appear in the provided code fragments. Rule 21.14 forbids using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings; the shown code does not perform any memcmp calls nor any string comparisons of null-terminated char arrays.

Details justifying omission of fragments from investigation:
- lfs_dir_seek and lfs_dir_seek_ contain only integer/structure field operations and calls to other functions; they do not call memcmp or perform any char* or C-string operations.
- lfs_pair_cmp compares elements of two lfs_block_t arrays using integer equality (paira[0] == pairb[0], etc.). This is element-wise integer comparison, not a memcmp on strings, and thus not relevant to Rule 21.14.
- lfs_dir_rewind_, lfs_dir_fetch, and the shown typedefs only manipulate blocks, offsets, and structures; they don't handle null-terminated strings or call memcmp.
- Macros and calls visible (LFS_TRACE, LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, lfs_dir_fetchmatch) have no visible memcmp usage in the supplied code. If investigation should cover other files, those functions/macros (and any implementation of lfs_dir_fetchmatch) should be inspected for memcmp usage, but they are not present in the provided fragments.

Because no memcmp calls or C-string comparisons are present in the provided code, there are no suspicious fragments to report for Rule 21.14.
